evidence.snippet: It has been suggested <mark>Charles</mark> suffered from the endocrine disease acromegaly and a combination of rare genetic disorders often transmitted through recessive genes, including combined pituitary hormone deficiency and distal renal tubular acidosis.[3] <mark style="background-color: rgba(255,0,0,0.41013902352000003)">However,</mark> this is speculation; the authors of the most significant study state that 'it has <mark style="background-color: rgba(255,0,0,0.20829318584)">not</mark> been demonstrated the disabilities suffered by <mark>Charles</mark> <mark>II</mark> were <mark style="background-color: rgba(0,255,0,0.1270044144)">caused</mark> by the expression of detrimental recessive alleles inherited from common ancestors.[4] Regency[edit] As <mark>Charles</mark> was only 3 years old when Philip died on 17 September 1665, <mark>Mariana</mark> was appointed his regent, advised by a Regency Council, until he became a legal adult at the age of 14. Her competence is difficult to assess; even modern <mark style="background-color: rgba(0,255,0,0.2734528)">opinions</mark> often <mark style="background-color: rgba(0,255,0,0.036086148)">reflect</mark> contemporary views on the role of women and <mark>Mariana</mark> as a 'foreigner,' while the second half of the 17th century was one of <mark style="background-color: rgba(255,0,0,0.12224735504)">almost</mark> continuous <mark style="background-color: rgba(0,255,0,0.2765864995)">crisis</mark> for Europe in general, <mark style="background-color: rgba(255,0,0,0.20829318584)">not</mark> only Spain.[5] Recent studies argue she attempted significant reforms but these were compromised by internal political feuds.[6] The struggle between 'Austrian' and 'French' factions, respectively led by <mark>Mariana</mark> and <mark>Charles'</mark> illegitimate half-brother John of <mark>Austria</mark> the Younger, was worsened by <mark>Spain's</mark> division into the Crowns of Castile and Aragon.

<mark>Charles</mark> <mark>II</mark> <mark style="background-color: rgba(0,255,0,0.0195316077)">Quotes</mark> <mark>Charles</mark> <mark>II</mark> (1661-1700), the last Hapsburg king of <mark>Spain,</mark> reigned from 1665 to 1700. Known as "the Bewitched," he was a foolish and weak monarch at a time when <mark>Spain</mark> direly needed strong leadership. <mark>Charles</mark> <mark>II,</mark> the son of Philip IV of <mark>Spain</mark> and his second wife, <mark>Mariana</mark> of <mark>Austria,</mark> was born in Madrid on Nov.

mother: <mark>Mariana</mark> of <mark>Austria</mark> siblings: Balthasar <mark>Charles,</mark> Ferdinand Thomas <mark>Charles</mark> of <mark>Austria,</mark> Francis Ferdinand of <mark>Austria,</mark> Infante of <mark>Spain,</mark> John of <mark>Austria</mark> the Younger, Margaret Theresa of <mark>Spain,</mark> Maria Theresa of <mark>Spain,</mark> Philip Prospero, Prince of Asturias Died on: November 1, 1700 City: Madrid, <mark>Spain</mark>

Margaret of <mark>Austria</mark> and Philip III of <mark>Spain;</mark> grandparents and great-grandparents of <mark>Charles</mark> <mark>II</mark> The father of Philip III was Phillip <mark>II,</mark> and he also married his nice. This was Anne of <mark>Austria,</mark> the eldest daughter of his sister Archduchess Maria of <mark>Austria</mark> and Maximilian <mark>II,</mark> Holy Roman Emperor. Anne was suposed to marry her cousin Don Carlos of <mark>Spain,</mark> the only son of her maternal uncle Philip <mark>II,</mark> but <mark style="background-color: rgba(0,255,0,0.1260882361)">unfortunately</mark> he died in 1568.

FANDOM <mark>Charles</mark> <mark>II</mark> of <mark>Spain</mark> <mark>Charles</mark> <mark>II</mark> of <mark>Spain</mark> is the King of <mark>Spain</mark> and the husband of Marie Louise d Orl ans, a niece of Louis XIV of France. Contents Biography Early Life <mark>Charles</mark> was born in Madrid to Philip IV of <mark>Spain</mark> and his second wife, <mark>Mariana</mark> of <mark>Austria.</mark>

<mark style="background-color: rgba(255,0,0,0.41013902352000003)">However,</mark> the 17th century was a period of <mark style="background-color: rgba(0,255,0,0.2765864995)">crisis</mark> for many European states and <mark>Spain</mark> was <mark style="background-color: rgba(255,0,0,0.20829318584)">not</mark> alone in facing these problems.[8] Feuds between those who ruled in <mark>Charles'</mark> name did little to help but it is debatable how far they or he can be held responsible for long-term trends predating his reign; the Monarchy proved remarkably resilient and when <mark>Charles</mark> died was largely intact.[9] Reign[edit] <mark>Charles</mark> was three years old when his father, Philip IV, died on 17 September 1665; as he was a legal minor, his mother <mark>Mariana</mark> was appointed Queen Regent by the Council of Castile. While <mark>Charles</mark> theoretically ruled in his own name after her death in 1696, in reality his frequent ill-health meant power was often exercised by others. This resulted in bitter internal struggles for control of government, the long feud between his mother and illegitimate half-brother John of <mark>Austria</mark> the Younger being especially damaging.

Besides him, the other only <mark style="background-color: rgba(0,255,0,0.2833417033)">surviving</mark> <mark>child</mark> of Philip IV's first marriage was the Infanta Maria Theresa, who later became the wife of King Louis XIV of France. After Margaret, between 1655 and 1661, four more <mark>children</mark> (a daughter and three sons) were born from the marriage between Philip IV and <mark>Mariana</mark> of <mark>Austria,</mark> but only one <mark style="background-color: rgba(0,255,0,0.2833417033)">survived</mark> infancy, the future King <mark>Charles</mark> <mark>II</mark> of Spain.[1][3] Margaret <mark style="background-color: rgba(255,0,0,0.20829318584)">didn't</mark> develop the serious health issues and disabilities (because of the close consanguinity of her parents) that her younger brother had shown since his birth. During her childhood she was once seriously ill, but survived.[4] <mark style="background-color: rgba(0,255,0,0.2834043784)">According</mark> to contemporaries, Margaret had an attractive appearance and lively character.

This family <mark style="background-color: rgba(0,255,0,0.2147134179)">provided</mark> kings that reigned over vast territories that included Bohemia, Hungary, Portugal, Croatia, Germany, <mark>Spain,</mark> and, of course, <mark>Austria.</mark> In the reign of the 16th century s <mark>Charles</mark> V, with European kingdoms and colonies stretching to the Americas, it was said his was the empire on which the sun never sets. Habsburg <mark>Spain</mark> dissolved on November 1, 1700, <mark style="background-color: rgba(0,255,0,0.3183254997)">following</mark> the death of its last, and probably the most infamous, ruler of all: <mark>Charles</mark> <mark>II</mark> of <mark>Spain.</mark> <mark style="background-color: rgba(0,255,0,0.1256813696)">Although</mark> this king was granted the right to run a large and powerful kingdom, he is remembered as an infirm ruler, thanks to his many health disabilities and his poor intellect.

His mother was <mark>Mariana</mark> of <mark>Austria</mark> and she was the second wife of his father Phillip IV of <mark>Spain.</mark> <mark>Mariana</mark> was the daughter of Phillip s sister Maria Anna. That means, his new wife was his niece, which makes <mark>Mariana</mark> to be both <mark>Charles</mark> mother and cousin. If we start looking at the rest of the lineage, relationships get so freakishly complicated one has to wonder how this <mark>child</mark> was <mark style="background-color: rgba(255,0,0,0.20829318584)">not</mark> going to be messed up.

<mark>Mariana</mark> of <mark>Austria</mark> was born on 24 December 1634 as the daughter of Ferdinand III, Holy Roman Emperor and Maria Anna of <mark>Spain.</mark> At the age of 11, <mark>Mariana</mark> was betrothed to Balthasar <mark>Charles,</mark> Prince of Asturias, but he died just three months at the age of 16. Philip IV of <mark>Spain</mark> was now left without a male heir, and he was conveniently widowed too. He <mark style="background-color: rgba(0,255,0,0.2129802621)">decided</mark> to marry <mark>Mariana,</mark> who was also his niece, himself.

The mystery of why <mark>Charles</mark> <mark>II</mark> of <mark>Spain</mark> s head was full of water One of Europe s most powerful dynasties from the 15th through 20th centuries was the House of Habsburg, a royal German family, also known as the House of <mark>Austria.</mark> The reign of this strong political and military force, with its vast territorial <mark style="background-color: rgba(255,0,0,0.373749712)">claim,</mark> kingdoms and colonies, was an empire on which the sun never sets, stretching over the territories of Bohemia, Croatia, Hungary, Germany, <mark>Spain,</mark> Portugal, and to the Americas in the 16th century. The Habsburgs even <mark style="background-color: rgba(255,0,0,0.373749712)">claimed</mark> the crown of Holy Roman emperor in 1452.

Maria Anna of Neuburg Maria Anna of Neuburg (Spanish: <mark>Mariana;</mark> 28 October 1667 16 July 1740) was Queen of <mark>Spain</mark> from 1689 to 1700 as the second wife of King <mark>Charles</mark> <mark>II.</mark> Contents Life Born in Benrath Palace in Dusseldorf, she was the twelfth <mark>child</mark> of Philip William, Elector of the Palatinate, and Elisabeth Amalie of Hesse-Darmstadt.
